Can carbon-based nanomaterials revolutionize membrane fabrication for water treatment and desalination?
Yehia Manawi a, Victor Kochkodan a, Muataz Ali Hussein a, Moe A. Khaleel b, Marwan Khraisheh a, Nidal Hilal c,⁎ a Qatar Energy and Environment Research Institute (QEERI), Hamad bin Khalifa University (HBKU), Qatar Foundation, Doha, Qatar b Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6163, USA c Centre for Water Advanced Technologies and Environmental Research (CWATER), College of Engineering, Swansea University, Bay Campus, Swansea SA1 8EN, UK
H I G H L I G H T S
• Recent studies on the membrane preparation with CNMs have been summarized • CNM incorporation, in some cases, has a pronounced effect in creation of novel membranes • Further research is required to evaluate the feasibility of CNM membranes in water treatment
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: n.hilal@swansea.ac.uk (N. Hilal).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016.02.015 0011-9164/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al. desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx

Article history: Received 11 October 2015 Received in revised form 7 February 2016 Accepted 8 February 2016 Available online xxxx
Due to their exceptional mechanical, conductive and antibacterial properties carbon-based nanomaterials (CNMs) have been widely used in attempts to fabricate novel membranes for water treatment and desalination with advanced characteristics. This paper reviews the current state of the application of CNMs, including carbon nanotubes, graphene, graphene oxide, carbon nanofibers, MXene, carbide derived carbon and fullerene formembrane preparation. A brief description of different CNMs and their properties has been providedwith reference to membrane requirements. Thereafter the recent studies on themembrane fabrication/modificationwith CNMs as well as the properties of the developedmembranes have been critically summarised. It was shown that, in some cases, using CNMs results in novelmembraneswith high flux, high rejection, low-fouling, and enhanced conductive, thermal and mechanical properties. However, further research including determining the optimum CNM quantity and characteristics, feed-specificmembrane performance and long-term operability should be conducted to better evaluate the feasibility of CNM-based membranes in water treatment and desalination. This review paper is potentially important for researchers involved in the membrane fabrication using CNMs.

Keywords: Carbon-based nanomaterials Membrane fabrication Water treatment Desalination

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
A sharp growth in theworlds' population coupledwith urbanization has resulted in a rapidly increasing demand for fresh water [1]. More than 1.2 billion people in the world lack access to clean and safe drinking water and problems with water are expected to grow worse in the comingdecades [2]. Nowadays themembrane processes such as reverse osmosis (RO), nanofiltration (NF), ultrafiltration (UF), microfiltration (MF),membrane distillation (MD) and pervoparation (PV) are regarded as the most attractive methods for drinking water treatment, brackish and seawater desalination, waste water treatment and reuse [3]. Polymeric membranes currently are the most common on the market, however, there are still several problems with practical application of these membranes, which are related to their fouling, chemical,
, Can carbon-based nanomat .doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
mechanical and thermal stability [4,5]. This situation has compelled scientists to search for novel membrane to improve their performance and properties [6]. The advanced membranes should be designed to meet specific water treatment applications by tuning their structural and physicochemical characteristics, including hydrophilicity, porosity, membrane charge, and thermal and mechanical stability as well as introducing additional functionalities such as antibacterial, photocatalytic or adsorption capabilities. In recent years there has been a growing interest in using of nanomaterials for development of novel membranes with advanced properties [6]. Due to their exceptional mechanical, chemical and thermal stability and conductive and antibacterial properties carbon-based nanomaterials (CNMs) are among the most promising candidates to tackle this challenge [5,7–9].
Several research papers have been recently published on using some specific CNMs such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [7–11] and graphene oxide (GO) [12–17] in the membrane synthesis. This paper reviewers the current state of application of different CNMs, including CNTs, graphene, GO, carbon nanofibers (CNFs), MXene, carbide derived
erials revolutionize membrane fabrication for water treatment and .02.015
carbon and fullerene for membrane fabrication with focus at water treatment and desalination. The challenges facing preparation and application of CNT-based membranes are also outlined.

sections.heading: 2. CNMmaterials and their basic properties
sections.text:
The most common types of CNMs are CNTs, graphene, GO, CNFs, MXene, carbide derived carbon and fullerene (Fig. 1). Due to their unique characteristics such as high chemical, thermal, and mechanical
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al., Can carbon-based nanomat desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
strength, conductivity, optical properties and low density CNMs have been widely explored in chemistry and material science [18].
Since the first discovery in 1991 CNTs have attracted enormous research interest [19]. CNTs consist of a sheet of carbon atoms that are rolled into hallow smooth cylindrical tubes (Fig. 1a–d). Two types of CNTs, namely single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), which differ by the number of carbon atom cylindrical arrays arranged around the hallow nanotube core, have been developed and studied extensively. The properties of each of the two types of CNTs vary depending on the atomic
on microscopy (SEM) image of aligned bundles of CNTs [42,43], (c) transmission electron rain array [45], (f) schematic presentation of GO structure [44], (g) schematic presentation ] and (j) TEM of onion-like fullerene [49].
erials revolutionize membrane fabrication for water treatment and .02.015
configurations of the nanotube cylinders [19]. In general, CNT's unique structural and functional properties such as mechanical strength, conductivity along with their high aspect ratio have made these materials potential candidates for various applications in microelectronics [20], biomedical field [21], and composite reinforcement in polymers [22].
Graphene is another carbon material, which has been intensively studied for its potential exploitation in different fields [7,23–26]. Graphene is a layer of strongly packed carbon atoms that are joined together in a two dimensional honeycomb hexagonal lattice (Fig. 1e). It exhibits several attractive properties such as a light weight (1 m2 of graphene weighs around 0.77 mg), very high thermal conductivity (between 4.84 × 103 and 5.3 × 103 w/m K at room temperature [27]), relatively high electrical conductivity (in the order of 102 S/m) [28] and it is the strongest compound ever tested (100 to 300 times stronger than steel with an intrinsic tensile strength of 130 GPa and Young's modulus of 1 TPa) [29]. Graphene is considered as the building block of some other allotropes such as GO, CNFs and fullerene [30].
GO is a modified version of graphene with oxygen and hydrogen atoms being bonded to carbon atoms (Fig. 1f). Usually, GO is obtained by oxidizing graphene with strong acids and oxidizers [23]. The oxidation process introduces several functional groups such as hydroxyl, epoxy and carboxyl [31] to the graphene lattice. The presence of oxygen and hydrogen-based functional groups enables the nanosheets of GO to disperse well in water and other organic solvents, that would facilitate preparation of GO-based membranes [24].
CNFs are hollow core nanofibers consisting of a single graphite layer or double graphite layerswhich are stacked parallel or at a specific angle from the fiber axis [32,33]. The stacked layers are located next to each other and have different structures including parallel, cup-stacked and herringbone-like structure [34]. Fig. 1g shows one of the forms of CNFs of herringbone structure.
Metal carbides are a member of MAX phase groups [35]. The MAX phases are defined as layered, hexagonal carbides and nitrides, which have the general formula of Mn+1AXn, (MAX) where M is an early transition metal (such as: Ti, V, Cr, Nb, etc.), A is an A-group element (such as: Al, Si, Sn, In, etc.), X is either carbon and/or nitrogen and n is 1 to 3 [36]. MXenes consist of few atom-thick layers of transition metal-carbide or carbon-nitride [37]. Fig. 1i shows SEM image of 2D layered MXene. These compounds have been referred to MXenes as they are synthesized by etching the “A” layer from the MAX phase compounds which turns MAX into MXenes [37]. Those A-group-free MAX phase compounds exhibit metallic conductivity due to the existence of transition metal carbides and hydrophilic nature owing to oxygen-containing groups [37].
Carbide-derived carbon (CDC), which is also referred to as “tunable nanoporous carbon” is the name used to describe carbon materials which has been derived from either: 1) carbide precursors such as binary (e.g. TiC or SiC) or 2) ternary carbides (MAX phases such as Ti2AlC or Ti3SiC2) [38]. Moreover, CDCs can be derived from carbonitrides such as Si–N–C or from polymer-derived ceramics [39].
Fullerene is an allotrope of carbon which has a hollow structure that takes the shape of sphere, tube or ellipsoid (Fig. 1a and j) [40]. Spherical fullerenes look like balls and that's why they are sometimes referred to as “bucky-balls”. Structure wise, all fullerenes are similar to graphite which consists of arranged graphene sheets [40].
CNMs possess many valuable properties, which are attractive for membrane fabrication and modification [24]. For example, it was found that CNTs, graphene and GO inhibit the growth of bacteria when they are directly contactedwith bacterial cells [50]. Liu et al. [50] have showed that bactericidal properties of CNMs towards Escherichia coli bacteria increase in the row: graphite oxide b graphite b reduced GO b GO. The antibacterial properties of CNMs might be beneficial for preparation of low-fouling membranes. Conductive properties of CNTs [51] might be used for fabricating electrically conductive membranes [52]. Embedding hydrophilic CNMs in the membrane synthesis has been observed to increase hydrophilicity, flux and rejection of the prepared membranes
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al., Can carbon-based nanomat desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
[53,54]. Additionally, incorporation of MWCNTs into the membrane matrix enhances the mechanical properties in terms of Young's modulus and tensile strength [55]. It was also shown that embedding TiO2 coated MWCNTs into the membrane reduces the electron/hole recombination and improves the photocatalytic efficiency of the prepared membranes [56].
Thus, incorporation of CNMs in membrane preparation process could not only tune hydrophilicity, flux, rejection, chemical, thermal andmechanical stability of the preparedmembranes, but also introduce additional membrane properties such as antibacterial, photocatalytic and conductive properties [50]. For these reasons CNMs are currently widely studied in attempts to fabricate CNM-based membranes with advanced properties for water treatment [26,57–59], gas separation [60], and fuel cell applications [61].
3. CNMs in membrane fabrication and modification
As to membrane structure and nanomaterials location, fabricated CNMmembranes can be classified as i) freestanding CNM membranes, ii) surface modified composite membranes and iii) membranes with CNMs embedded into a polymer matrix.

sections.heading: 3.1. Freestanding CNM-based membranes
sections.text: Among different CNMs, GO and CNTs are most often used for preparation of the self-supporting carbon-based membranes.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Self-supporting GO membranes
sections.text:
The most common techniques to prepare freestanding GO membranes are vacuum filtration, spray/spin coating and a drop casting of GO nanosheets [24,31,57,62–64]. GO membranes can be described as an assembly of GO nanosheets, which forms interlocked layers that are packed and staked above each other; the gaps are created by the existing interlayer space [12]. A single GO nanosheet layer has an effective thickness of 0.5 nm while the lateral size can be tuned from hundreds of nanometers up to tens ofmicrometers [23]. It was reported that GO layers could be impermeable to vapors, gases and liquids; however, permeable to water molecules [65]. The permeability of water through the freestanding membrane was 1010 times faster than the helium due to the existence of an almost-frictionless flow of monolayer of water through the 2-dimensional capillaries between the closelyspaced graphene sheets [65]. It was also shown that the hydroxyl- and epoxy functional groups attached to the GO nanosheets are responsible for keeping the interlayer gaps between the grapheme sheets [66–72]. The fabricated freestanding GO membranes have been reported to be flexible and mechanically robust [66–68,73].
Xu et al. [74] have used vacuum filtration technique to fabricate GO/ TiO2 membrane by introducing TiO2 nanoparticles between GO nanosheets. The presence of the oxygen-based functional groups enables GO nanosheets to disperse easily inwater. The freestandingmembranes were fabricated by preparation of the stable GO–TiO2 aqueous dispersion followed by vacuumfiltration. The average pore size of the fabricated membrane was evaluated as 3.5 nm. It was claimed [74] that the incorporation of TiO2 into the membrane has the effect of intercalating GO nanosheets with TiO2 nanoparticles which has eventually increased the gaps between the nanosheets and created channels for water to pass. When NF tested with aqueous solutions of methyl orange and rhodamine B, the prepared membrane exhibited 100% rejection which indicates their potential applications in treatment of dye-containing waters. Fig. 2 depicts the assembly and filtration mechanism through the freestanding GO–TiO2 membrane.
A drop casting technique has been used by Sun et al. [31] to fabricate freestanding GO membranes with reduced intersheet gaps (0.82 nm). These membranes were tested for NF separation of sodium ions from copper, cadmium, manganese ions and molecules of rodamine B dye. It was shown that sodium ions have easily passed through the GO
erials revolutionize membrane fabrication for water treatment and .02.015
Fig. 2. The assembly/filtration mechanism through GO–TiO2 freestanding film and an SEM image of the film's cross section [74].
membrane while copper ions and the dye molecules experienced slow permeation. As shown in Fig. 3, the passage of sodium ions through the GO membrane was through the membrane's nanocapillaries while the rejection of heavy metals was due to their coordination with functional groups on the GO membrane.
Using molecular dynamic simulations, Cohen and Grossman have recently suggested that graphene layers with nanopore diameters smaller than 0.55 nm can be used for water desalination and the salt rejection could be 2–3 times higher than for commercial RO membranes [75]. However, the potential concentration polarization effects with nanoporous graphene have been not considered in this study. Nicolaï et al. [48] based on molecular dynamic simulations claimed that water permeability through ultrathin up to 10 nm freestanding GO membranes are to be approximately 400 L/m2d MPa that is orders of magnitude higher thanwhat is currently achievedwith ROmembranes. It was also suggested that water permeability in GO membranes is a function of pore size and pore spacing where highest permeability was achieved for pore size and spacing of 1.2 and 1.0 nm, respectively [48]. However, the reported simulation data have been not well supported with the experimental studies. In desalination tests with a self-supporting
graphene membrane despite high flux, that ranged between 80 and 276 L/m2 h MPa depending on the number of GO nanosheets, a low salt rejection of 6–46% was shown [23]. A flux of 21.8 L/m2 h and 40% of salt rejection was reported by Han et al. [76] for NF GO membrane. The low salt rejection was explained by presence of unzipped slits during the fabrication of GO sheet membranes. Choi et al. [77] found that the rejection of NaCl with the GO multilayer deposited on the surface of the polysulfone (PS) porous support was limited to 12.2%. The authors suggested that GO multilayers alone do not provide sufficient NaCl rejection. The possible low rejection of GO multilayers might be also caused by structural defects in GO nanosheets imposed by graphene oxidation.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Freestanding CNT membranes
sections.text:
Two main types of freestanding CNTmembranes, namely isoporous and bucky-paper like ones have been developed and evaluated for water treatment and desalination [78]. Isoporous CNT membranes are CNT-containing membranes where CNTs are aligned as cylindrical pores across an impermeable matrix material which forces the fluid flow to take place only through the hollow CNT interior. On the other
Cd+2 ions with freestanding GO membrane [31].
hand, Bucky-paper CNT membranes can be described as a random arrangement of CNTs into a paper-like, nonwoven structure [78]. The main advantage of this type of CNT membranes is the presence of an extremely large porous 3Dnetwork and a high specific surface area [78].
3.1.2.1. Isoporous CNT membranes. In their pioneering work, the isoporous CNT membranes were first fabricated by Hinds et al. [79,80] who prepared vertically-aligned CNT membranes and showed that the fluid flow was 2–3 order of magnitude larger that the flow estimated by conventional fluid flow theory. An array of aligned CNTs was incorporated across a polymer film to form a well-ordered nanoporous membrane structure which was confirmed by electron microscopy, anisotropic electrical conductivity, gas flow, and ionic transport studies [79,80]. It was also reported that the selectivity of CNTs and the control the flow of fluid through the CNT pores can be enhanced by functionalization of the tip of CNTs [78]. Likewise, Holt et al. [81] have measured the gas and water flow through microfabricated membranes with less than 2 nm diameter VA-CNTs acting as pores. The gas flow have been found to exceed the value predicted by Knudsen diffusion model by an order of magnitude whereas the water flow exceeds the values predicted by the continuum hydrodynamics model by more than 3 order of magnitude. The permeability of the gas and water through theVA-CNTmembranes has been reported to be orders ofmagnitude higher than the values reported for commercial polycarbonate membranes despite having pore sized an order of magnitude smaller which enhances the selectivity and mass flow of VA-CNT membranes [81]. Schematic presentation of the procedure to fabricate VA-CNT– epoxy matrix membranes is shown in Fig. 4(a–c).It was suggested that due to excellent fluid transport properties these membranes might be attractive forwater desalination [48,82]. Using simulationmodels Hummer et al. [83] showed that the chain of water molecules can enter into and experience fast frictionless conduction through the CNTs. This is the result of the hydrogen bonding in the chain of water molecules that enter the hydrophobic inner core of CNT tube aswell as negligible interactions between the carbon atoms and water molecules in the interior. Dynamic stimulation by Thomas and McGaughey [84] showed that water transport through CNTs essentially depends on their diameter. It was revealed that increasing the CNT diameter from 0.66 to 0.93 nm reduced ion rejection from 100 to 95%, indicating that ion rejection is sensitive to changes in nanotube diameter [85]. Recently it was showed that a cut-off CNT radii ranging between 0.34–0.39 nm ensures water
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al., Can carbon-based nanomat desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
passage into the CNT interior while excluding sodium and chloride ions [86]. However, there is a challenge of achieving high water flux in CNTs of diameter of 0.6–0.8 nm [87].
Despite that fact that many studies on modeling of water flux and salt rejection with CNT membranes have been presented, so far there is only few experimental reports on the feasibility of these membranes in water treatment. Baek et al. [88] have prepared VA-CNT membranes by incorporating CNTswith pore diameter of 4.8 nm in a polymer epoxy matrix. VA-CNT membranes with pore density of 6.8 × 1010 pores/cm2 have been prepared using the water-assisted thermal chemical vapor deposition technique. The performance of the modified membrane in terms of rejection and flux has been compared with the commercially available UF membranes during filtration of 100 kDa polyethylene oxide (PEO) solutions, The biofouling tendency of VA-CNT membranes was evaluated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 bacterial suspension with concentration of 1 × 107 cell/mL. The modified membrane has been found to produce almost 3 times higher permeate flux compared with the commercial UFmembrane (Fig. 4d) at similar values of PEO rejection (78% for VA-CNT membrane and 82% for the commercial one). The VA-CNT membrane showed better biofouling resistance with approximately 15% less flux drop and almost 2 log scale bacteria attachment reduction that the UF membrane.
Lee et al. [89] have prepared VA-CNTmembrane with inner pores of 6 nmand outer pores of 7 nm,with an extremely highwater permeability of 30,000 L/m2 × h × bar. It was also shown that the CNTwallsmight impede the adhesion of bacterial cells and resist the formation of biofilm [89]. It should be mentioned, that despite the excellent fluid transport properties of VA-CNTs has been reported, however, agglomeration and alignment control of nanotubes in the membrane matrix during preparation is still big challenge.
3.1.2.2. Bucky paper CNT membranes. Bucky-paper is a term used to refer to mats of randomly arranged CNTswhich are entangled and fabricated by any papermaking process [78]. Van der Waals interactions are responsible for the strong aggregation of CNTs forming the cohesive bucky-paper structure. Different methods such as vacuum assisted filtration [90], layer-by-layer (LBL) deposition [53], or electrospinning [91] have been suggested for preparation of bucky paper CNT membranes.
Mamedov et al. [92] have fabricated freestanding SWCNT membranes using LBL technique. The fabricated membranes have been

Peng et al. [90] have fabricated freestanding CNT membranes using vacuum assisted filtration of the dispersion of oxidized SWCNTs through a polycarbonate membrane (Fig. 6a). Once immersed in ethanol, the ultrathin films were peeled off from the polycarbonate support. The resulting CNT films had an average thickness of few tens to hundreds of nm (Fig. 6b). The self-supporting membrane has been fabricated from MWCNTs with diameters ranging between 10 and 15 nm and a length of 150–300 μm. Vacuum-assisted filtration through 0.2 μm PES support followed by peeling off of the deposited layer has been used to form a self-supporting CNT membrane.

The membrane has exhibited high porosity of 90%, which is 20% higher than for the polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE)membrane, hydrophobicity (contact angle 113°) and high thermal conductivity (2.7 kW/m2 h) [93]. The prepared membranes possessed salt rejection of 99% and distillate flux of 12 kg/m2 hwhen testedwith synthetic seawater (35 g/L NaCl solution) [93]. However, when compared to the conventional PTFE membrane, the prepared CNMmembrane did not result in higher flux during DCMD. Also the membrane showed slight deterioration in the physical structure due to the dealignment of CNTs forming “micro-cracks” [50].
Bhadra et al. [94] have used COOH-functionalizedMWCNTs to fabricate freestanding CNT membrane. The use of carboxylated MWCNTs have been found to increase the polarity and interaction between the membrane surface and the water vapor which in turn enhance MD desalination performance as shown in Fig. 7a. The distillate flux of 19.2 kg/ m2 h with the MWCNT membrane has been found to be superior compared with conventional polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) membrane. Additionally, the prepared membranes have demonstrated stable desalination performance which is evidenced by the long operation (100 days) of carbon nanotube immobilized membrane (CNIM) and functionalized carbon nanotube immobilized membrane (CNIM-f) without any significant flux drop (Fig. 7b).

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Self-supporting membranes made from other CNMs
sections.text:
The self-supporting CNF membranes have been fabricated by Liu et al. [91] using the electrospinning of polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofiber followed by their peroxidation, carbonization and post-treatment with ZnCl2. The fibers of the fabricated membranes have been observed to have a smooth surface with a uniform size (average diameter of 250 nm). The prepared membranes exhibited high hydrophilicity, flexibility and large specific surface area. In capacitive desalination experiments, the prepared membrane has demonstrated relatively high capacitance and hence relatively high salt sorption while testing with 500 mg/L NaCl solution. The contact angle has been decreased from 134° for the unmodified CNFmembrane down to 21° when the ZnCl2 activated CNF membrane has been fabricated.
CDC has also been used to prepare freestanding membranes which can be used in capacitive desalination. Porada et al. [96] found that self-supportingmembranes based onmesoporous silicon CDCwith a bimodal distribution of pore sizes at 1 and 4 nmhad exhibited the highest salt electrosorption capacity per unit mass when testing with 5 mM NaCl solution.
Table 2 summarizes someof the experimental studies on the fabrication, simulation and performance of graphene, GO, CNF and CDC-based membranes.
3.2. Surface membrane modification with CNMs
Surface modification of polymer membranes with CNMs has been used innumerous studies in the last decades to improve themembranes separation properties, fouling resistance and chemical stability [52,77, 102–105].
Kimet al. [102] havemodifiedROpolyethersulfone (PES)membrane with amino groups using LBL coating on the membrane surface a negatively charged GO nanoparticles followed by deposition of positively charged layer of amino functionalized GO. The modified membrane exhibited high water flux of 28 L/m2 h and salt rejection of 98%.
Choi et al. [77] have also used a LBL technique to modify the surface of PA membranes with GO and GO with amino groups (aGO) nanosheets. The modified membrane demonstrated good resistance to chlorine-induced degradation due to the presence of the GO protective layer on the surface of PAmembrane (Fig. 8a). The chemically-inert nature of GO nanosheets enables the GO coating layer to act as a chlorine barrier for the underlying PA membrane, resulting in a suppression of themembrane degradation upon chlorine exposure. Also, water contact angle has been reduced from 71° for the pristine PA membrane to 26° for GO modified membrane (Fig. 8b) and the surface roughness of the GO modified PA membrane has been reduced more than twice (Fig. 9). As a result the antifouling resistance of the modified membranes have been essentially improved and the permeate flux has increased by 10%, while the salt rejection from 2000 mg/L NaCl aqueous solution was found to be reduced only by 0.7%.
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al., Can carbon-based nanomat desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
Gao et al. [103] havemodified the surface of PSmembranes with GO nanosheets and TiO2 nanoparticles using the similar LBL technique. The modifiedmembrane has demonstrated improved surface hydrophilicity and high flux of 45 L/m2 h. The photo-catalytic performance of themodifiedmembraneswas evaluated during ultraviolet (UV)-initiated degradation of methylene blue (MB) dye in batch and filtration experiments. Coating a TiO2 layer on the PS membrane resulted in active photodegradation of MB under UV light (Fig. 10b). Coating a GO layer on the PSmembrane led to very compatible photocatalytic performance (Fig. 10c), suggesting that GO, as a semiconductor and photocatalyst itself, has a band-gap energy similar to that of TiO2. The deposition of a TiO2–GO double layer, however, significantly improved photocatalytic performance of themembrane under not only UV but also sunlight irradiation. As seen in Fig. 9d, the efficiency of MB photodegradation with the TiO2–GO membrane under UV and under sunlight is very compatible and is much higher compared with TiO2-modified (Fig. 10b) and GO-modified (Fig. 10c)membranes. This observation suggests that integration of TiO2 andGOdecreases the band-gap energyof each individual semiconductor so that sunlight is able to activate electrons in these materials and hence enhance the photocatalytic efficiency.
It is known that, one of the main problems arising upon the operation of the membrane module in water treatment applications is the membrane fouling, which seriously hampers the application of membrane technologies [106]. The membrane fouling propensity depends largely on the choice of membrane material, its surface chemistry and porous structure [104]. CNMs such as CNTs and GO have demonstrated

ability to inactivate bacteria upon direct contact with bacterial cells [29, 60]. Perreault et al. [107] have studied the effect of modifying themembrane surfaces with GO to improve the antibacterial behavior of thin film composite (TFC) PA membranes. The GO nanosheets were bonded to themembrane surface through amide coupling between the carboxyl groups in the GO and PA membrane layer (Fig. 11). It was shown that 65% of E. coli cells have been inactivated at direct contact with the modified membrane for 1 h. It was found that GO inactivates bacteria by initiating the cell membrane damage, mediated by physical disruption [50,108], and eventually extraction of lipid from the cell membrane [62]. SEM images (Fig. 11) show that the cells contacted with GOmembrane appear to be flattened or are shrunk compared to the cells attached to control membrane. This bactericidal behavior has been introduced to the GO modified membrane without compromising of the membrane's transport properties. Moreover, water contact angle for GO-surface-modified membrane decreased to 46° compared with 81° for the pristine membrane due to introducing of oxygen-containing functional groups to the membrane surface.
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al., Can carbon-based nanomat desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
Hung et al. [109] have used a pressure assisted filtration to deposit GOmultilayers on the surface of PANmembrane. In PV tests with aqueous solution of 70 wt.% isopropyl alcohol (IPA), the permeate flux and the water recovery have been found to be 4137.0 g/m2 h and 99.5%, respectively. It was suggested that the high membrane selectivity is mainly due to the highly-ordered and packed GO laminates which allowed water to pass through while preventing the passage of IPA molecules. According to the authors [64] water molecules are adsorbed at GO hydrophilic terminals before being diffused through the hydrophobic carbon core, which forms a water passage channel that enhance the permeate flux (Fig. 12a, b). The passage of the first water molecules through GO layers facilitates the path of the subsequent molecules as adsorbed water layer pushes the GO nanosheets apart (widening the d-spacing).
Zhang et al. [110] have combined GO with oxidized MWCNTs to modify the surface of PVDFmembranes. It was reported that GO aggregation can be avoided in the presence of the long and tortuous oxidized CNTs, which tend to connect adjacent GO nanosheets. The modified

GO–MWCNTmembrane has shown a significant increase in the hydrophilicity and antifouling property which outperform CNT-modified or GO-modified membranes. A hybrid membrane with a ratio of 1:9 (GO:MWCNTs) has exhibited a significant reduction in the contact angle (53°) compared to PVDF membrane (78°) while the water flux of the 1:1 (GO:CNTs) membrane was improved by 252% compared to pristine PVDF membrane.
SWCNTs and MWCNTs have been also used for surface membrane modification to enhance the flux and reduce membrane fouling. Amini et al. [111] have modified the surface of TFC PA membrane with amine functionalized MWCNTs (0.01, 0.05 and 0.1%) using interfacial polymerization technique. The surface hydrophilicity of the modified membrane has been found to increase with MWCNT loading. High salt rejection and water permeability were observed when the modified membranes were tested in forward osmosis (FO) system with 10 mM NaCl solution as feed and 2 M NaCl as a draw solution (Fig. 13). The permeate flux of the modified membrane has been found to be 160% higher than for conventional TFC membranes with an average value of 95.7 L/m2 h.
Hashaikeh et al. [52] prepared composite electrically conductive membranes by deposition of MWCNTs on the surface of 0.22 μm PVDF membranes. The deposited MWCNTs allow the composite membrane to function as a cathode in an electrochemical system that included the electrically conductive membrane, the salt water as an electrolyte and a stainless steel counter anode. The efficiency of the cleaning procedure in the flux recovery has been proved with CaCO3 and yeast suspensions. As seen in Fig. 14, due to efficient surface cleaning a sharp increase in normalized flux was observed after 2.5 h filtration of
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al., Can carbon-based nanomat desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
CaCO3 suspension: 63% (with the electrolysis cleaning) compared to 24% in control experiment (without the electrolysis cleaning). It can be also seen that the shorter filtration interval has a higher flux recovery after electrolysis cleaning (Fig. 14). The authors suggested that during a short filtration cycle, a looser fouling layer is deposited on the membrane surface and such a layer can more easily be removed from the membrane surface when compared with the denser fouling layers formed at prolonged filtration. The cleaning mechanism during the electrolysis process was explained by the evolution of gases forming micro-bubbles at the membrane surface which remove the foulant material out from the membrane. The conductive properties of MWCNTs based membranes enables in situ membrane self-cleaning, thus providing a non-destructive and renewable approach for the mitigation of the membrane fouling.
Ren et al. [112] have prepared MXene-based composite polymeric membranes with enhanced mechanical strength and fouling resistance by mixing MXene nanoparticles with polymeric solutions followed by vacuum filtration. The thickness of the composite membranes has been found to be between hundreds of nanometers and tens of micrometers. The presence of the layered structure of MXene membranes has created nanochannels for the passage of water, dissolved molecules and ions. The charge and hydration radius of ions have been found to control the permeation rate with a critical value ion size about 4.0 Å and other species with larger sizes were found to be rejected by the membrane [112].
Ti3C2-based MXene membranes have been found to be selective towards Cu2+ ions [112]. The existence of the negative charge on the
O sheets depicting the hydrophilic O-rich edge, to which H2Omolecules are adsorbed, and onolayer H2O molecules [109].
erials revolutionize membrane fabrication for water treatment and .02.015
surface of hydrophilic Ti3C2-based MXene membrane and the silt pores interlayer are the main reasons behind the concept of size and charge selectivity in the obtained membranes.
Chae et al. [113] modified the surfaces of MF ceramic (anodisc) membranes with fullerene (C60) using dip coating technique followed by drip-draining of the excess solvent and finally by solvent evaporation. Fig. 15 shows the effect of surface properties of fullerene modified membranes on the respiratory activity and surface attachment of E. coli K12 bacteria. Fullerenes coating has been observed to significantly increase the hydrophobicity and decrease the zeta potential of the membrane surface. This has the effect of sharply reducing the number of bacteria attached to the membrane surface. Moreover, the bacterial respiratory activity in a suspended growth environment has also been inhibited and decreased with increasing of C60 loading on the membrane surface. This indicates that C60 fullerene might be used as an anti-fouling agent to mitigate the membrane biofouling.
It should be noted that similar to surface coating with organic modifiers, the coating or deposition of CNMs onto membrane surfaces also faces the problem of loss or leaching. Therefore, further studies should be performed to strengthen the adhesion between the membrane surface and CNMs to maintain the long-term improvement of antifouling properties. Also, careful control andmonitoring of the nanoparticles released from the modified membranes are necessary to minimize potential (eco) toxicity effects [114].
Tables 3 and 4 list the recent studies on surfacemembranemodification with GO, fullerene and CNTs.

sections.heading: 3.3. CNM incorporation in membrane matrix
sections.text:
Incorporation of CNMs into polymer membrane matrix has been reported to affect membrane structure and properties, including hydrophilicity,flux, rejection,mechanical strength and antimicrobial behavior [59,117–119].
It was shown that the membrane surface hydrophilicity was enhanced by incorporating hydrophilic CNMs [53,120]. Zhang et al. found [53] the contact angle for the oxidized MWCNT/PA membranes decreased from 70° to 25° with increasing MWCNT loading from 0 to 0.2 wt.% due to providing more hydrophilic functional groups to the membrane surface. Similarly, when preparing poly(amine ester)functionalized MWCNTs/PVDF) membranes, Zhao et al. [120] reported improved surface hydrophilicity, which could be attributed to the increased surface coverage of hydrophilic –OH groups from the nanofillers.
ne on the respiratory and attachment activity of E. coli K12 cells [113]. DAPI stands for 4′,6-

Incorporation of CNMs into polymer matrix also changes the porosity, pore size and subsequently flux and rejection of the preparedmembranes. It was shown [54] that the incorporation of 0.1 wt.% MWCNTs into RO PA membranes doubles the water flux through the membrane up to 28.1 L/m2 h while maintaining high salt rejection (N90%). The authors suggested thatMWCNTs in the polymermatrix offers channels for the increased water transport which explains the water flux. Zhang et al. [53] also reported a large increase in water flux up to 71.0 L/ m2 h (almost 2.7 times higher than water flux with a pristine PA membrane), when 2000 mg/L NaCl solution was filtered through PA membrane embedded with 0.1% functionalized MWCNTs.
It was found that incorporation of the oxidized MWCNTs into PS membrane matrix led to an increase in the surface pore size with MWCNT loading, but after a certain MWCNTs dosage, the pore size of the fabricated membrane began to decrease [121]. This trend was consistent with the water flux data that showed a convex profile with increasing nanofiller loading. The similar results were reported also when GO was added to membrane casting solutions. Xu et al. [122] and Zhao et al. [123] have claimed thatwhen small amounts of functionalized GO is used, the porosity and pore size of themembrane increase; however, these characteristicswill be loweredwhenmore additives are used. It was found that when the GO amount surpassed 0.05%, the viscosity of the casting solution increased and the porosity of the fabricated membranewas noticeably decreased [124]. Liu et al. [125] also reported that due to the increase in the viscosity of the polymer mixture the formation of large pores will be prevented. It was shown that the addition of hydrophilic substance in the dope solution leads to an accelerated solvent and non-solvent exchange (caused by thermodynamic immiscibility) and thus encourages formation of a more porous membrane structure. With a further increase in the filler loading, however, the viscosity of the casting solution would increase, slowing down the precipitation. Under these delayed demixing conditions, a top membrane
layer will be denser and thicker with lower porosity and low degree of pore interconnectivity due to the high concentration of the casting polymer solution [126]. Lee et al. [127] reported that the incorporation of GO in the casting solution reduces the formation of cracks and macrovoids in the surface membrane layer.
Many efforts were focused at improving the interaction between CNMs and polymermatrix, especially for thosematerials that are inherently hydrophobic such as CNTs [12]. A common approach to improve the dispergation of CNTs within polymermatrix is to generate hydroxyl and carboxyl functional groups on CNTs surface with acid treatment [121].
Zhao et al. [128] incorporated carboxy-functionalized MWCNTs into PA matrix. The modification procedure involved mixing PA solution with MWCNTs followed by membrane fabrication using the interfacial polymerization between metaphenylene diamine and trimesoyl chloride. MWNTs were functionalized by treating pristine MWCNTs with mixed H2SO4 and HNO3 acids. It was shown that introducing carboxy-functionalized MWNTs into PA matrix leads to an increase of negative charge of the membrane's surface compared with pristine PA membrane. The separation performance (flux and salt rejection with 2000 mg/L NaCl solution) has been enhanced, and the contact angle of the MWNT-modified membrane has been found to decrease with increasing the MWCNT loading (Fig. 16a, b). The overall antifouling resistance of the modified membrane has been observed to exceed that of the pristine PA membrane (Fig. 16c).
Celik et al. [129] have incorporated MWCNTs (0.5–4 wt.%) into PES membranes. The performance of themodifiedmembrane has been tested during surface water treatment with total organic content of 7 mgC/ L. As seen in Fig. 15d, MWCNT/PES membranes have exhibited higher permeate flux compared to neat PESmembrane indicating that incorporation of CNTs into polymericmatrix is capable to reduce themembrane fouling.
Fig. 16. (a) The effect ofMWNT loading in PA/MWNTmembrane on separation performance, (b): contact angle of PA/MWCNTmembranes at differentMWNT loadings, (c): flux decline of pristine PA and PA/MWCNTmembranes during BSA filtration (theMWCNT loading in themembraneswas 0.1 wt.% [128] and (d):Water flux of theMWCNT/PES (C/P) blendmembranes as a function of the transmembrane pressure during surface water treatment. C/P varied from 0 to 4% [129]. C/P is the ratio between MWCNTs to PES content.
Several researchers have embedded pre-functionalized GO into polymer casting solution using different modifiers such as: hyperbranched polyethyleneimine (HPEI) [118], 3-amino propyl triethoxy silane (APTS) [122] and isocyanate [123]. The functionalized GO was mixed with PS [118] and PVDF [122] solutions and the membrane were casted using phase inversion technique. The preparation procedure followed to prepare HPEI-GO/PS membrane is depicted in Fig. 17a.
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al., Can carbon-based nanomat desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
The prepared HPEI-GO/PS membrane has been reported to reject polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) (molecular weight of 30,000–70,000) and polyethylene glycol (PEG) (molecular weight of 20,000) by 90% and 85%, respectively. It was also shown that hydrophilicity of the prepared membranes increasewithHPEI-GO content (Fig. 17b). The GO-modified membranes: isocyanate-f-GO/PS [123] and APTS f-GO/PVDF [122] have been found to reject BSA by 95% and 57%, respectively. TEM images of
angles of prepared membranes with various content of HPEI-GO [118].
erials revolutionize membrane fabrication for water treatment and .02.015
E. coli cells have shown that the bacterial cells have lost their cellular integrity, and the cytoplasm flowing out when contacting with HPEI-GOmodified membranes [118].
Zinadini et al. [130] fabricated NF GO/PESmembranes with different GO loading. Fig. 18 depicts the fouling resistance ratio of the prepared membranes during filtration of milk powder solution (8000 mg/L) which shows that the 0.5 wt.% GO membrane exhibited the best anti-biofouling behavior. Additionally, this membrane has exhibited high water flux (around 65.2 kg/m2 h) and high dye rejection (99%). The authors correlated the presence of the hydrophilic groups and higher hydrophilicity of the prepared membranes to the improvement in their performance.
Zhao et al. [110] have fabricated UF GO/PVDFmembrane. This membrane has exhibited improved flux of 26.5 L/m2 h and BSA rejection of 44.3%. The modified membranes have demonstrated smaller fouling, obviously due to the higher hydrophilicity (the contact angle of the modified membrane decreased to 61° compared with 73° for pristine PVDF membrane) and surface morphology.
Using phase inversion technique, Lee et al. [119] have prepared GO/ PS membrane for waste water treatment in the membrane bioreactors (MBRs). The authors have reported that the incorporation of 1 wt.% of
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al., Can carbon-based nanomat desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
GO nanoplatelets to the polymer matrix has the effect to decrease the membrane fouling and reduce the frequency of chemical cleaning by fivefold. The extent of the membrane fouling has been expressed in terms of the reduction of the trans-membrane pressure (TMP). Fig. 19 shows TMP profile with operating time when GO-incorporated PS membranes were used in MBR for waste water treatment. The GO embedding in membrane matrix is believed to increase the hydrophilicity and impede themembrane biofouling owing to the low interfacial energy between a membrane surface and feed. Moreover, negative charge on membrane surface also reduces attachment and accumulation of biofoulants. This can enable the potential of fabricating GO-basedmembranes for highly-fouling membrane applications such as wastewater treatment.
Another interesting approach to reduce membrane fouling is to use the conductive properties of some CNMs. Recently, it has been reported that CNTs embedded into polymer membranes are capable of bacterial inactivation and bio-fouling prevention once an electrical bias is applied [131]. Lannoy et al. [131] prepared electrically conductive polymernanocomposite (ECPNC) thin film membranes which demonstrated biofilm-preventing capabilities at high bacteria and organic material loadings. The aqueous suspension of carboxylatedMWCNTs (b8 nmdiameter; 10–30 μm length) was deposited onto a PES membrane. Then MWCNTs covered PES support was immersed in a 2.0% (w/w) aqueous solution of MPD for 30 s, slightly dried, and then immersed in a 0.15% (w/w) solution of TMC dissolved in hexane for 30 s. The scheme of incorporation of the CNTs into the membrane matrix is presented in Fig. 20.
As shown in Fig. 21, in the case of ECPNC membranes connected to the voltage generator (1.5 V squarewave, 16.7 mHz), the flux reduction and recovery behavior were significantly different from control experiments. Whereas flux loss did occur for the electrically charged ECPNC membranes, the rate of flux decline was up to three times lower than in the control experiments, with a 45% flux decline observed only after 80 h, compared to 22 and 30 h in experiments for control types 2 and 3, respectively. Additionally after 1 min of cross-flow flushing (with no cleaning agents), water flux was consistently and reproducibly recovered from92%up to 100%of the initialflux. Thus, ECPNCmembranes with applied voltage demonstrated much longer resistance to flux decline and flux was completely recoverable with one minute of crossflow flushing. SEM images of themembrane surface showed that control membranes were fouled with dense biofilms, whereas ECPNC membranes with applied voltage showed clean surfaces lacking any evidence of bacterial attachment or extracellular polymeric substances.
It is known that the amide linkage in commercial TFC PAmembranes is susceptible to attack by chlorine, which results in the membrane degradation. Therefore, considerable attention has been paid to development of chlorine-resistant membranes [132]. Introducing CNMs into PA structure might be used as one of the approaches to tackle this challenge. When MWNCTs were incorporated into PA thin-film layer at a loading of 0.1–1.0 wt.%, the prepared membrane showed a much improved chlorine resistance [132]. It was believed that the interactions between the carboxylic group of modified MWCNTs and the amide bond made the membrane more stable against chlorine. Similarly, Zhao et al. [54] found the MWCNTs embedded PA membrane had a better chlorine resistance and attributed this phenomenon to the protection of amide linkage by electron-rich MWCNTs.
Incorporation of MWCNTs into membrane matrix also showed positive effects on the mechanical strength of the prepared membranes compared to conventional PAmembranes in terms of Young's modulus, toughness, and tensile strength [55]. By loading 2 wt.% MWCNTs, the tensile strength of MWCNTs/PAN membranes was increased over 97% due to the combined effects of bonding between nanotubes and thematrix and the decreased membrane porosity [133]. The tensile strength and elongation-at-break of the (APTS f-GO/PVDF) membrane casted by Xu et al. [122] have been measured and found to experience an enhancement by 69% when compared with non-functionalized GO/PVDF

membrane due to the strong interaction between the polymer matrix and APTS f-GO.
Introduction of CNTs into membrane matrix may have also a synergistic effect on photocatalytic properties of the prepared membranes. Vatanpour et al. [56] studied the effect of embedding of TiO2 coated MWCNTs into the PESmatrix onmembranemorphology, physicochemical properties and anti-biofouling characteristics. Duringwhey solution filtration, the prepared membrane exhibited improved fouling resistance, which was attributed to the lower surface roughness and synergistic photocatalytic activity. The presence of CNTs was believed to reduce the electron/hole recombination and improve the photocatalytic properties of TiO2/MWCNT/PES membranes [49].
The incorporation of CNFs embeddedwith GO to fabricate capacitive desalination membranes have been investigated by Bai et al. [134]. The adjusted membrane has been fabricated using the electrospinning of PAN and GO before being carbonized and activated with steam. The electrosorptive properties of the prepared membrane have been shown to outperform the activated carbon-based membranes due to high electrosorptive capacity of CNF-based membranes (as a result of their shallower pores of smaller diameter and higher electrical conductivity). The embedding of GO in the membrane matrix has been correlated with the increase in the electrical conductivity of the membrane. This has the effect of lowering the ion transport resistance through the membrane and might enhance the performance of the capacitive desalination process.
Penkova et al. [135] using the phase inversion technique prepared poly-(phenylene-iso-phthalamide) membranes with incorporated fullerene (C60). The fullerene incorporated membranes exhibited considerably high permeate flux and higher flux recovery during both dynamic UF and static sorption experiments with proteins solutions. Fig. 22 shows the flux reduced recovery (FRR) in dynamic and static tests for neat PA membranes and the membrane samples modified by
Please cite this article as: Y. Manawi, et al., Can carbon-based nanomat desalination?, Desalination (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.desal.2016
5wt.% soot, fullerene C60 and CNTs. As seen themembranes incorporated with fullerene and CNTs demonstrated high values of FRR of 0.8–0.9, while FRR was close to 0.4 for neat PA membrane and soot-embedding membrane sample. The authors suggested that incorporation of fullerene C60 and nanotubes might “interlock” PA sorption centers responsible for proteins sorption.
Furthermore, C60 fullerene has also been incorporated with polyphenylene oxide (PPO) to fabricate membranes for PV separation of aqueous organic mixtures [136]. The polymeric solution has been
erials revolutionize membrane fabrication for water treatment and .02.015
prepared by mixing PPO with 2% fullerene in toluene. The membrane with thickness of 50–80 μm was prepared by the removal of toluene from the solution poured onto cellophane at 40 °C. It was reported that incorporating fullerenes with PPO membranes has been found to enhance PV separation of aqueous solutions of ethanol and ethyl acetate. Sha et al. [137] have incorporated fullerene C60with ethyl cellulose polymer for the casting membrane which can be used in the gasoline desulfurization. The increase in the load of fullerene has been found to increase the diffusion and sorption coefficients of toluene, thiophene and cyclohexene that eventually enhances the total permeation coefficient of the components. When compared with the neat ethyl cellulose membranes, the fullerene embedding membranes showed enhanced permeate flux with improved sulfur enrichment.
Tables 5 and 6 summarize some of the recent studies on CNMs incorporating in polymeric membranes.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this review, application of CNMs such as CNTs, GO, CNF, MXene, CDC and fullerene for membrane modification and fabrication has been discussed. More than 120 publications were found on the subject in the scientific literature over the last few decades. It was shown that besides tuning the membrane's hydrophilicity, porosity, charge, thermal andmechanical stability, the incorporation of CNMs can induce membranes with some advanced additional properties such as lowfouling, conductive, photocatalytic, etc. It was shown that, in some cases, the using of CNMs in membrane fabrication has a pronounced effect in creation of novel membranes with high flux, rejection, lowfouling and conductive properties, enhanced thermal and mechanical stability. However, there is still a challenge to produce reliable CNM based membranes with long-lasting enhanced performance in water treatment and desalination. It should be also pointed out that so far all reported studies on the CNM based membranes have been performed only on a small lab scale.
The role of membrane structure and surface properties in CNM membrane performance is still not thoroughly understood. Based on dynamic simulation it was shown that water fluxes through GO and CNTs based membranes to be two to five orders of magnitude greater than those predicted by Hagen–Poiseuille law, however, in experimental studiesmuch smaller flux values and a rather low salt rejectionwere found. With such varying and contradicting findings, it is clear that further research needs to be undertaken to provide a comprehensive understanding between porous structure-surface properties and the performance of CNM-based membranes.
In principle, ultrathin GO membranes can provide ultrahigh water flux, however, fragmentation in GO membrane layer might results in low rejection values. Also mechanical strength and durability of these membranes remain a challenge. The development of cracks within freestanding membranes (producing low quality flux) as a result of the weak attractive forces between the constituting CNMs has been reported. So, further optimization in preparation of freestanding CNM membranes is required to fabricate mechanically stable samples, which can withstand the operating pressure.
As to CNM embedded membranes, approaches for better compatibility of CNMswith polymermatrix need to be further explored because the compatibility will determine both the membrane performance and the stability of CNTs within the membrane. Regarding VA-CNT membranes, so far their preparation is still a complicated and time consuming process, and search for robust fabrication procedure is required. Also evaluation the cost-effectiveness of large scale CNTs-based membrane fabrication should be performed, because the economic feasibility of scaling up such membranes remains questionable. Finally, monitoring of the long-term stability of CNTs-based membranes under real sourcewater quality and application environments is required to determine the true feasibility of CNM based membranes in water treatment and desalination applications.

Graphene is considered as the building block of some other allotropes such as GO, CNFs and fullerene [30].
Usually, GO is obtained by oxidizing graphene with strong acids and oxidizers [23].
The oxidation process introduces several functional groups such as hydroxyl, epoxy and carboxyl [31] to the graphene lattice.

The presence of oxygen and hydrogen-based functional groups enables the nanosheets of GO to disperse well in water and other organic solvents, that would facilitate preparation of GO-based membranes [24].

The stacked layers are located next to each other and have different structures including parallel, cup-stacked and herringbone-like structure [34].

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 11 October 2015 Received in revised form 7 February 2016 Accepted 8 February 2016 Available online xxxx Due to their exceptional mechanical, conductive and antibacterial properties carbon-based nanomaterials (CNMs) have been widely used in attempts to fabricate novel membranes for water treatment and desalination with advanced characteristics. This paper reviews the current state of the application of CNMs, including carbon nanotubes, graphene, graphene oxide, carbon nanofibers, MXene, carbide derived carbon and fullerene formembrane preparation. A brief description of different CNMs and their properties has been providedwith reference to membrane requirements. Thereafter the recent studies on themembrane fabrication/modificationwith CNMs as well as the properties of the developedmembranes have been critically summarised. It was shown that, in some cases, using CNMs results in novelmembraneswith high flux, high rejection, low-fouling, and enhanced conductive, thermal and mechanical properties. However, further research including determining the optimum CNM quantity and characteristics, feed-specificmembrane performance and long-term operability should be conducted to better evaluate the feasibility of CNM-based membranes in water treatment and desalination. This review paper is potentially important for researchers involved in the membrane fabrication using CNMs. © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
